text: Also, I couldn't help wondering what the 1980s would have looked like had social media and the Internet already been invented. A lot uglier. A lot like today.
author: continetti

text: As I say in the review, I found myself surprised by how often I agreed with Thatcher during these arguments, even as I recognized that events legitimized and vindicated Reagan.
author: continetti

text: The diplomacy of Thatcher and Reagan was more contentious than has been understood. I was struck by the relevance of the concepts about which they debated: national sovereignty, deterrence, and international terrorism.
author: continetti

text: Richard Aldous of Bard College & @aminterest has a new book on the relationship between Margaret Thatcher and Ronald Reagan that I highly recommend. My review @NRO
author: continetti

author: continetti

text: Finally, it's important to "think in time." The first 70 years of the conservative movement, intellectual and political, operated under far more averse circumstances than today. And it was able to secure concrete victories, not least the collapse of the Soviet Union.
author: continetti

text: It's worth wondering why the GOP is less open to forms of solidaristic conservatism than conservative writers are. It's not just donors. It's also the activists, the party rank-and-file, and, ultimately, voters.
author: continetti

text: President Trump has had a far more difficult time disrupting this latter consensus among politicians than he has among conservative writers and scholars.
author: continetti

text: I feel they overestimate the strength of the consensus they are fighting. The conservative intellectual movement today is fractured, diffuse, and exploring multiple avenues of development. The consensus among Republican elected officials, on the other hand, is ironclad.
author: continetti

text: A group of young(ish) conservative writers and thinkers stakes a claim in the battle to define conservatism in the twenty-first century.
